content: this is dmg this is the real dmg we're going to be talking about ruined
passages all right so now we're going to show you
a ruined passageway done in the 2.5 D style admitted by DMS Cody so I've done
a corner piece as you see in video 2 how we created this now I'm using the walls
as you can see with the pencil I have just traced where the walls are going to
be and then I just randomly trace some corners and I got started on ripping out
the first layer so I'm just going to continue on with that
and so you rip out the first layer of cardboard to get down to the second
layer so we rip out the corrugation I don't need to be terribly tidy with this
as it is a ruined passageway so again we're not trying to be super artistic
here the actual effect works well if it's a little bit grungy so if you want
to like me and you're a little bit pedantic you can clean it out but that's
all you need to do so now I was going to grab some cardstock and lop off a big
piece and I'm going to create some tiles azzam busted tiles that are going to be
half falling into those holes so just cut out some random shapes I'm not
measuring anything I'm just doing this totally by random and cutting up and
trimming the edges a little bit just give it a little bit of curved edges to
simulate the advanced painting method to see in video 5 so cutting off the edges
trimming it and placing it in the holes just where I want the tiles to be just
so I can see if the shapes are working well I'm just lopping it off and you
know this is very easy if you're going to do any kind of ruins passages or ruin
rooms or anything like that you can basically do the same technique they
don't need to be in the hole so I'm just do it for effect you can just place them
on the actual tile itself so that look you can actually create a hole on put it
half over the hole just to make it look like there is obviously pieces missing
but this is just what I'm going to do in this one okay so now we're grab the hot
glue and we're going to put on the walls so
juster let the hot glue heat up quite a lot it it will be quite runny and that's
what we want for this so stick on the walls don't know how long it'll take to
dry didn't time it but it does dry very quickly so you can get this done in a
matter of minutes and lop off the walls on the edges and you can see here that I
haven't have the lines measured and so you can go from that point as we did in
video to and create the corner corner tile so again placing the wall lop it
off and more up glue and essentially just repeating the same process from
video two so now I'll have when the one settlement wall is locked off we're now
going to go into the edges and just play some hot glue there you can see the hot
glue is dripping off the glue gun so it's very runny at the moment if it
drips onto the tile that is fine it is a ruined passage it just you drop to hit
the ground there just wipe some off that's fine because we're gonna have
bits of debris and stuff all over the tile so it's not going to be out of
place so again I'm just placing blobs hot glue just to stick those tiles down
in the actual holes themselves and there's going to be a lot of wisps so
careful not to burn yourself as you can see I'm dropping a lot of glue it's
getting messy really really quickly and yeah very important that the the broken
tiles are are well stuck down you don't want them falling off later on and
revealing unpainted areas and things like that so it's good to have it all
glued down properly so now our ongoing is down into the actual corrugation
underneath the main layer I'm just putting some hot glue just to seal it
off and also behind the broken tiles just to secure them as I said before so
into the corrugation and that'll look like you know dirt and
rubble and things underneath the e/m underneath the the flooring and it'll
seal it all so you can't really see the corrugation it's okay when you see the
walls from the side of corrugation because it kind of looks like you know
rocks on top of one another but yeah just to seal it up the bottom layer so
what I'm doing here is I'm just running the glue gun back and forth back and
forth back and forth just to have sort of a ridged effect so that looks like
broken up ground underneath the underneath the floor so it's just back
and forth squeezing a little bit of glue out just running it back and forth in
different directions and then create like lines and criss crossing and
everything that just look like the dirt underneath the paving again you add a
little bit down in the edges and that's what it's starting to look like so what
we're going to do now is grab a bag of big rubble so if you check out the
rubble video video 15 yeah you can see how we did the rubble and just bits of
polystyrene and big globs of glue and whack them into the into the various
areas don't go too overboard you do want to be able to play on these tiles so
always consider where the minis are going to be and now also look at the
height as well try not to go above what would have been a third layer of
cardboard just to keep that sort of three layer height restriction I've put
on myself you don't have to do that if you don't want to it's just how I prefer
to do it to keep in the spirit of DM Scotty's 2.5 D method so now I'm just
going to ring and go over the polystyrene with some hot glue just to
hold it in place better and also when we spray paint on a coat this you know the
some of these hot glue bits will remain intact and hold down the base
of other polystyrene but we'll get to that in a moment so I'm running a nice
long strip just down the edges there and we're going to add in some small bits of
rubble now so you're going to grab your bag of small rubble just drop down a
whole bunch of rubble into that hot glue we've just placed and push it in with
your fingers push it right into the glue to make sure that's it's all sticking
there and you don't have to go so overboard as I have in with this but
this is obviously a demonstration tile just to show to you you can do little
bits and pieces here but this is a this major damage happened in here as
obviously in some kind of fight or you know things were uptil Dan door it's
been breaking down for hundreds of thousands of years or something silly
that's what's happened in this corridor so again I'm just going to go over the
polystyrene with some of the hot glue just to hold it in place and have
something there if anything gets eaten away by the spray paint we're going to
be using and just keep going over and right so now before we undercoat I'm
going to put some black acrylic paint on the polystyrene only so this I'm just
going to use some boots of speed to speed it up so the reason for this is
because when you spray the spray paint you would normally use to undercoat the
tiles as in video three you are going to eat away at the polystyrene so we don't
want that to happen so by applying the acrylic paint that lessens the amount
that gets eaten away so now I have based it I've used the methods in video three
four and five to get to this point and I'm just finishing off some of the black
edging with my paintbrush and so that's what it looks like the moment so what I
have done is I've I have got a bit of that sort of eating away effect that's
happening in the polystyrene and I've just aged that a little as well as all
the individual tiles I've edged those as in video 5 and just to show a
consistency with with the rest of the piece so now I'm going to take some
brown acrylic paint and I'm just going to paint into the
ground bits that we were talking about earlier can you hear the cat meow he
wants to come in want to steal my cardboard so gonna just jump on some
boots of speed here and show you you know just really just go it's painting
dirt so go over it a few times with the brush just so that you get into all the
nooks and crannies and starting to look pretty good now and then I'm going to
add some white acrylic paint to it and just to make the color a little bit
lighter and then I'm going to go put more Brown on top of that again so it's
a really mucky muddy mess underneath there imagine maybe there's some damp or
something and then you can see I'm just spotting some Brown over the tile as
well and the spot just looks like you know bits of dirt or sprayed up or have
been kicked around as people have walked through and a little bit of edging
around those things so here we go this is the tile in amongst other tiles so it
fits in very nicely and it looks very good as you can see in the shot here and
close-up there of the effect of the polystyrene being eaten away by the
spray paint so it's sort of a start to make it look like you know sand and and
and corruption and things in in the actual bits so you can also then add the
rubble piles in further rooms just to complete the effect without having to
create whole tiles if you want to see future videos subscribe you can also
check out my playlist as well which feature all the videos I've been doing
in the different categories that there are so check out the Facebook page and
